10.07.text:
I am so proud to stand here today as Prime
Minister of four nations in one United Kingdom.

29.49.text:
I was always clear about why we called that
referendum.

33.95.text:
Duck the fight – and our union could have
been taken apart bit by bit.

39.59.text:
Take it on – and we had the chance to settle
the question.

44.04.text:
This Party has always confronted the big issues
for the sake of our country.

49.41.text:
And now…
…England, Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland…

54.28.text:
…we are one people in one union and everyone
here can be proud of that.

68.25.text:
And we can all agree, during that campaign
a new star – a new Conservative star – was

78.65.text:
born…
…someone who’s going to take our message

81.25.text:
to every corner of Scotland: our very own
Ruth Davidson.

103.17.text:
The lead-up to that referendum was the most
nerve-wracking week of my life.

110.11.text:
But I can tell you the best moment of my year.
It was June 6th, the 70th anniversary of D

118.53.text:
Day.
Sam and I were in Bayeux, in France, with

123.28.text:
my constituent, Patrick Churchill…
…no relation to the great man – but a

128.52.text:
great man himself.
Patrick is 91 years old – and 70 years ago,

134.83.text:
he was there fighting fascism, helping to
liberate that town.

139.45.text:
I’ll never forget the tears in his eyes
as he talked about the comrades he left behind..

147.01.text:
…or the pride they all felt in the job they
had done.

152.60.text:
As we walked along the streets he pointed
out where he had driven his tank…

156.29.text:
…and all along the roadside there were French
children waving flags – Union Jacks – the

164.04.text:
grandchildren of the people he had liberated.
Patrick’s here today with his wife Karin

170.29.text:
– and I know, like me, you’ll want to
give them the warmest welcome.

213.22.text:
When people have seen our flag – in some
of the most desperate times in history – they

218.12.text:
have known what it stands for.
Freedom. Justice. Standing up for what is

224.19.text:
right.
They have known this isn’t any old country.

227.82.text:
This is a special country.
June 6th this summer. Normandy.

234.60.text:
I was so proud of Great Britain that day.
And here, today, I want to set out how in

241.17.text:
this generation, we can build a country whose
future we can all be proud of.

247.23.text:
How we can secure a better future for all.
How we can build a Britain that everyone is

253.81.text:
proud to call home.
The heirs to those who fought on the beaches

259.65.text:
of Northern France are those fighting in Afghanistan
today.

264.72.text:
For thirteen years, young men and women have
been serving our country there.

270.48.text:
This year, the last of our combat troops come
home – and I know everyone here will want

276.45.text:
to show how grateful and how proud we are
of everyone who served.

296.88.text:
But the end of the Afghan mission does not
mean the end of the threat.

301.50.text:
The threat is Islamist extremist terrorism
– and it has found a new, hellish crucible

307.97.text:
– with ISIL, in Iraq and Syria.
These people are evil, pure and simple.

316.71.text:
They kill children; rape women; threaten non-believers
with genocide; behead journalists and aid

322.91.text:
workers.
Some people seem to think we can opt out of

327.28.text:
this. We can’t.
As I speak, British servicemen and women are

332.44.text:
flying in the skies over Iraq.
They saw action yesterday.

337.79.text:
And there will be troops on the frontline
– but they will be Iraqis, Kurds, and Syrians…

342.90.text:
…fighting for the safe and democratic future
they deserve.

347.92.text:
We are acting in partnership with a range
of countries – including those from the

355.51.text:
There is no “walk on by” option.
Unless we deal with ISIL, they will deal with

362.27.text:
us, bringing terror and murder to our streets.
As always with this Party, we will do whatever

369.87.text:
it takes to keep our country safe.
And to those who have had all the advantages

379.27.text:
of being brought up in Britain, but who want
to go and fight for ISIL – let me say this.

387.15.text:
If you try to travel to Syria or Iraq, we
will use everything at our disposal to stop

392.62.text:
you:
Taking away your passport; prosecuting, convicting,

396.51.text:
imprisoning you…
…and if you’re there already – even

399.92.text:
preventing you from coming back.
You have declared your allegiance.

404.74.text:
You are an enemy of the UK – and you should
expect to be treated as such.

425.93.text:
When it comes to keeping Britain safe, I had
one man by my side for four years.

456.58.text:
When he was a teenager, he didn’t only address
the Tory party conference…

460.68.text:
…he read Hansard in bed…
…and had a record collection consisting

466.38.text:
of one album by Dire Straits and dozens of
speeches by Winston Churchill.

479.48.text:
All I can say is this: that boy became a fine
Parliamentarian…

484.67.text:
…a brilliant Foreign Secretary…
…our greatest living Yorkshireman…

487.15.text:
…and someone to whom I owe an enormous debt
of gratitude: William Hague.

499.42.text:
William, there’s one more task I want you
to carry out: bringing fairness to our constitution.

522.39.text:
During that referendum campaign we made a
vow to the Scottish people that they will

526.63.text:
get more powers – and we will keep that
vow.

531.14.text:
But here’s my vow to the people of England,
Wales and Northern Ireland.

537.77.text:
I know the system is unfair.
I know that you are asking: if Scotland can

542.67.text:
vote separately on things like tax, spending
and welfare….

546.39.text:
….why can’t England, Wales and Northern
Ireland do the same?

550.07.text:
I know you want this answered.
So this is my vow: English votes for English

556.14.text:
laws – the Conservatives will deliver it.
We’ve delivered a lot these past four years…

577.18.text:
…but we’ve had to do it all in a coalition
government.

581.82.text:
Believe me: coalition was not what I wanted
to do; it’s what I had to do.

587.37.text:
And I know what I want next.
To be back here in October 2015 delivering

601.39.text:
…leading a majority Conservative Government.
So where do we want to take our country?

620.24.text:
Where do I want to take our country?
During these four years, I hope that the British

627.08.text:
people have come to know me a little.
I’m not a complicated man. I believe in

633.57.text:
some simple things.
Families come first. They are the way you

638.39.text:
make a nation strong from the inside out.
I care deeply about those who struggle to

644.94.text:
get by…
…but I believe the best thing to do is help

648.25.text:
them stand on their own two feet – and no,
that’s not saying “you’re on your own”,

653.74.text:
but “we are on your side, helping you be
all you can.”

657.65.text:
And I believe in something for something;
not something for nothing.

663.37.text:
Those who do the right thing, put the effort
in, who work and build communities – these

667.87.text:
are the people who should be rewarded.
All of this is underpinned by a deep patriotism.

677.04.text:
I love this country – and my goal is this:
To make Britain a country that everyone is

683.19.text:
proud to call home.
That doesn’t just mean having the fastest-growing

688.36.text:
economy, or climbing some international league
table.

691.68.text:
I didn’t come into politics to make the
lines on the graphs go in the right direction.

696.75.text:
I want to help you live a better life.
And it comes back to those things I believe.

704.59.text:
A Britain that everyone is proud to call home
is a Britain where hard work is really rewarded.

711.39.text:
Not a free-for-all, but a chance for all…
…the chance of a job, a home, a good start

716.28.text:
in life…
…whoever you are, wherever you are from.

721.31.text:
And by the way – you never pull one person
up by pulling another one down.

739.85.text:
this Party doesn’t do the politics of envy
and class warfare…

744.85.text:
…we believe in aspiration and helping people
get on in life – and what’s more, we’re

755.39.text:
proud of it.
The past four years have been about laying

762.78.text:
the foundations for that Britain.
The next five will be about finishing the

767.72.text:
job.
Put another way – if our economic plan for

771.56.text:
the past four years has been about our country
– and saving it from economic ruin…

776.44.text:
…our plan for the next five years will be
about you, and your family – and helping

782.66.text:
you get on.
But Conservatives know this.

788.70.text:
Nothing comes easy.
There’s no reward without effort; no wealth

793.64.text:
without work; no success without sacrifice…
…and we credit the British people with knowing

799.33.text:
these things too.
Other parties preach to you about a Brave

804.73.text:
New World…
…we understand you have to start with the

808.41.text:
real world and make it better.
So let other politicians stand on stages like

814.76.text:
this and promise an easy life. Not me.
I am here today to set out our Conservative

822.21.text:
commitment for the next five years.
If you want to provide for yourself and your

830.19.text:
family, you’ll have the security of a job…
…but only if we stick to our long-term economic

836.54.text:
plan.
If you work hard, we will cut your taxes…

841.26.text:
…but only if we keep on cutting the deficit,
so we can afford to do that.

847.36.text:
For those wanting to buy a home, yes – we
will help you get on that housing ladder…

852.40.text:
…but only if we take on the vested interests,
and build more homes – however hard that

857.65.text:
is.
We will make sure your children get a great

861.04.text:
education; the best education…
…but only if we keep taking on everyone

866.43.text:
who gets in the way of high standards.
For those retiring, we will make sure you

873.31.text:
get a decent pension; and real rewards for
a life of work…

877.12.text:
…but only if we as a country accept we all
have to work a bit longer and save a bit more.

885.06.text:
It’s pretty simple really: a good job, a
nice home, more money at the end of the month,

892.45.text:
a decent education for your children, a safe
and secure retirement.

897.46.text:
A country where if you put in, you get out.
A Britain everyone is proud to call home.

905.08.text:
And a real long-term plan to get there.
It starts with more decent jobs.

916.34.text:
And look how far we’ve come.
Today there are 1 million 800 thousand more

921.91.text:
jobs in our country than there were in 2010.
We are creating more jobs here in Britain

928.35.text:
than in the whole of Europe put together.
1.8 million jobs.

934.49.text:
You know – when Britain is getting back
to work, it can only mean one thing…

939.57.text:
…the Conservatives are back in Government.
So here’s our commitment for the next five

961.02.text:
years.
What the economists would call: the highest

964.41.text:
employment rate of any major economy.
What I call: full employment in Britain.

971.08.text:
Just think of what that would mean.
Those who can work, able to work…

976.40.text:
…standing on their own two feet, looking
at their children and thinking “I am providing

980.52.text:
for you.”
We can get there – but only if we stick

984.59.text:
to our plan.
Companies are coming from all over the world

989.41.text:
to invest and create jobs here.
That’s not happened by accident.

993.68.text:
It’s because they see a Government rolling
out the red carpet for them, cutting their

998.16.text:
red tape, cutting their taxes.
So here is a commitment: with the next Conservative

1003.83.text:
Government – we will always have the most
competitive corporate taxes in the G20…

1009.34.text:
…lower than Germany, lower than Japan, lower
than the United States.

1027.29.text:
But George said something really important
in that brilliant speech on Monday.

1034.25.text:
A message to those global companies:
We have cut your taxes – now you must pay

1041.59.text:
what you owe.
We must stick to the plan on welfare too.

1055.54.text:
With us, if you’re out of work, you will
get unemployment benefit…

1059.68.text:
…but only if you go to the Job Centre, update
your CV, attend interviews and accept the

1065.66.text:
work you’re offered.
As I said: no more something-for-nothing.

1071.05.text:
And look at the results: 800,000 fewer people
on the main out-of-work benefits.

1079.44.text:
In the next five years we’re going to go
further.

1083.47.text:
You heard it this week – we won’t just
aim to lower youth unemployment; we aim to

1088.86.text:
abolish it.
We’ve made clear decisions.

1092.41.text:
We will reduce the benefits cap, and we will
say to those 21 and under: no longer will

1098.04.text:
you have the option of leaving school and
going straight into a life on benefits.

1103.25.text:
You must earn or learn.
And we will help by funding three million

1108.39.text:
Apprenticeships.
Let’s say to our young people: a life on

1112.04.text:
welfare is no life at all…
…instead: here’s some hope; here’s a

1116.47.text:
chance to get on and make something of yourself.
What do our opponents have to say?

1139.65.text:
They have opposed every change to welfare
we’ve made – and I expect they’ll oppose

1145.06.text:
this too.
They sit there pontificating about poverty

1148.96.text:
– yet they’re the ones who left a generation
to rot on welfare.

1154.23.text:
And while we’re at it: let’s compare records.
Under Labour, unemployment rose. With us,

1163.84.text:
unemployment is falling faster than at any
time for 25 years.

1167.49.text:
Under Labour, inequality widened. With us,
it’s narrowed.

1171.51.text:
Those are the facts.
So let’s say it loudly and proudly…

1175.64.text:
…with Britain getting off welfare and back
to work…

1178.56.text:
…the real party of compassion and social
justice today is here in this hall – the

1191.61.text:
Conservative Party.
It’s not just the job numbers that matter

1203.83.text:
– it is the reality of working life for
people in our country…

1209.24.text:
…especially the lowest-paid.
Anyone should be free to take on different

1216.23.text:
jobs so they can get on.
But when companies employ staff on zero hours

1221.78.text:
contracts and then stop them from getting
work elsewhere, that’s not a free market

1228.28.text:
– it is a fixed market.
In a Britain that everyone is proud to call

1232.34.text:
home, people are employed, they are not used.
Those exclusive zero hours contracts that

1238.77.text:
left people unable to build decent lives for
themselves – we will scrap them.

1254.93.text:
But there’s still more injustice when it
comes to work, and it’s even more shocking.

1264.43.text:
Criminal gangs trafficking people halfway
around the world and making them work in the

1269.23.text:
most disgusting conditions.
I’ve been to see these – houses on terraced

1275.20.text:
streets, built for families of four, cramming
in 15 people like animals.

1280.29.text:
To those crime lords who think they can get
away with it, I say…

1284.51.text:
No: not in this country; not with this party.
…with our Modern Slavery Bill we’re coming

1289.81.text:
after you and we’re going to put a stop
to it once and for all.

1300.46.text:
Once you have a job, I want you to take home
more of your own money.

1313.62.text:
If you put in, you should get out – not
hand so much of it to the taxman.

1318.50.text:
That’s why these past four years, despite
everything, I’ve made sure we provide some

1323.67.text:
relief to taxpayers in our country – especially
the poorest.

1328.02.text:
No income tax until you earn £10,000 a year
– and from next April, £10,500 a year.

1333.99.text:
Three million people taken out of income tax
altogether.

1339.69.text:
A tax cut for 25 million more.
And our commitment to you for the next five

1345.37.text:
years: we want to cut more of your taxes.
But we can only do that if we keep on cutting

1354.40.text:
the deficit.
It’s common sense – tax cuts need to be

1359.72.text:
paid for.
So here’s our plan.

1362.41.text:
We are going to balance the books by 2018,
and start putting aside money for the future.

1369.09.text:
To do it we’ll need to find £25 billion
worth of savings in the first two years of

1374.33.text:
the next Parliament.
That’s a lot of money, but it’s doable.

1379.86.text:
£25 billion is actually just three per cent
of what government spends each year.

1384.40.text:
It is a quarter of the savings we have found
in this Parliament.

1388.62.text:
I am confident we will find the savings we
need through spending cuts alone.

1395.01.text:
We will see the job through and get back into
the black.

1399.52.text:
And as we do that, I am clear about something
else.

1404.69.text:
We need tax cuts for hardworking people.
And here and now, I have a specific commitment.

1423.71.text:
Today, the minimum wage reaches £6.50 an
hour, and before long we’ll reach our next

1430.68.text:
goal of £7.
I can tell you now that a future Conservative

1435.65.text:
Government will raise the tax-free personal
allowance from £10,500 to £12,500.

1463.09.text:
That will take 1 million more of the lowest
paid workers out of income tax – and will

1469.37.text:
give a tax cut to 30 million more.
So with us, if you work 30 hours a week on

1476.30.text:
minimum wage, you will pay no income tax at
all. Nothing. Zero. Zilch.

1496.40.text:
Lower taxes for our hardworking people…
…that’s what I call a Britain that everyone

1501.11.text:
is proud to call home.
But we will do something else.

1510.32.text:
The 40p tax rate was only supposed to be paid
by the most well-off people in our country…

1516.43.text:
…but in the past couple of decades, far
too many have been dragged into it: teachers,

1522.46.text:
police officers.
So let me tell you this today.

1526.95.text:
I want to take action that’s long overdue,
and bring back some fairness to tax.

1533.19.text:
With a Conservative government, we will raise
the threshold at which people pay the 40p

1543.19.text:
…in the next Parliament we will raise it
to £50,000.

1555.54.text:
So here’s our commitment to the British
people:

1576.07.text:
No income tax if you are on Minimum Wage.
A 12 and a half thousand pound tax-free personal

1581.05.text:
allowance for millions of hardworking people.
And you only pay 40p tax when you earn £50,000.

1588.37.text:
So let the message go out:
With the Conservatives, if you work hard and

1592.69.text:
do the right thing…
…we say you should keep more of your own

1595.86.text:
money to spend as you choose.
That’s what our long-term economic plan

1600.85.text:
means for you.
And while I’m on the subject of the big

1621.33.text:
economic questions our country faces - on
spending, on tax – did you hear Ed Miliband

1627.58.text:
last week?
He spoke for over an hour, but didn’t mention

1632.43.text:
the deficit once. Not once.
He said he ‘forgot’ to mention it.

1640.72.text:
Ed – people forget their car keys, school
kids sometimes forget their homework…

1657.38.text:
be Prime Minister of this country, you cannot
forget the biggest challenge we face.

1667.06.text:
A few weeks ago, Ed Balls said that in thirteen
years of Government, Labour had made ‘some

1693.92.text:
Excuse me?
You were the people who left Britain with

1696.83.text:
the biggest peacetime deficit in history…
…who gave us the deepest recession since

1700.88.text:
the war…
…who destroyed our pensions system, bust

1703.64.text:
our banking system…
…who left a million young people out of

1706.88.text:
work, five million on out-of-work benefits
- and hundreds of billions of debt.

1711.39.text:
Some mistakes?
Labour were just one big mistake.

1728.39.text:
And five years on, they still want to spend
more, borrow more, tax more.

1736.27.text:
It’s the same old Labour, and you know what?
They say that madness is doing the same thing

1744.04.text:
over and over again but expecting different
results.

1747.61.text:
Well I say: madness is voting for this high
spending, high taxing, deficit ballooning

1753.55.text:
shower and expecting anything other than economic
disaster.

1772.87.text:
In a country that everyone is proud to call
home, you should be able to buy a home – if

1778.54.text:
you’re willing to save.
It shouldn’t be some impossible dream.

1784.11.text:
But we inherited a situation where it was.
Young people watched Location, Location, Location

1790.93.text:
not as a reality show – but as fantasy.
We couldn’t solve this housing crisis without

1797.82.text:
some difficult decisions.
The planning system was stuck in the mud – so

1802.04.text:
we reformed it…
…and last year, nearly a quarter of a million

1805.29.text:
houses were given planning permission.
Young people needed massive deposits they

1809.66.text:
just couldn’t afford…
…so we brought in Help to Buy.

1814.23.text:
Of course there were those who criticised
it…

1817.65.text:
…usually speaking from the comfort of the
home they’d bought years ago.

1821.61.text:
But let’s see what actually happened.
They said Help to Buy would just help people

1827.48.text:
in London…
…but 94 per cent of buyers live outside

1831.65.text:
the capital.
They said it would help people with houses

1838.79.text:
They said it would cause a housing bubble…
…but as the Bank of England has said, it

1842.56.text:
hasn’t.
So here’s our renewed commitment to first-time

1847.07.text:
buyers: if you’re prepared to work and save,
we will help you get a place of your own.

1854.26.text:
This conference we have announced a landmark
new policy.

1857.20.text:
It’s called Starter Homes.
We’re going to build 100,000 new homes – and

1862.58.text:
they’ll be twenty percent cheaper than normal.
But here’s the crucial part.

1868.62.text:
Buy-to-let landlords won’t be able to snap
them up.

1872.29.text:
Wealthy foreigners won’t be able to buy
them.

1875.15.text:
Just first-time buyers under the age of 40.
Homes built for you, homes made for you – the

1881.78.text:
Conservative Party, once again, the party
of home ownership in our country.

1897.16.text:
In a Britain that everyone is proud to call
home, you wouldn’t be able to tell a child’s

1903.24.text:
GCSEs by their postcode or what their parents
do.

1907.73.text:
There must be a great education for every
child.

1912.09.text:
A month ago I had this wonderful moment.
Florence is now 4 and just starting school,

1919.41.text:
so for the first time, all three of my children
are at the same primary school.

1924.66.text:
It was such a joy to take them to school together;
Florence clinging on for dear life until she

1931.32.text:
saw a new friend and rushed off to her classroom.
It’s hard to describe what a relief it is

1942.08.text:
as a parent to find a decent school for your
child.

1946.22.text:
It shouldn’t be a lottery.
What we have in our state primary in London

1952.66.text:
I want for every child in the country.
And we’re getting there.

1958.34.text:
More children in good or outstanding schools.
More children studying science, languages

1963.02.text:
and history.
A new curriculum – with five year olds learning

1966.15.text:
fractions; eleven years olds coding computers.
And 
the biggest change is the culture.

1985.04.text:
Teachers who feel like leaders again.
Who say: this is our school, we’re proud

1989.01.text:
of it, the children must behave in it, we
will not tolerate failure in it.

1994.29.text:
We’ve come so far - and make no mistake
– the biggest risk to all this is Labour.

2002.85.text:
You know what drives me the most mad about
them?

2006.75.text:
The hypocrisy.
Tristram Hunt, their Shadow Education Secretary

2012.01.text:
– like me – had one of the best educations
money can buy.

2017.26.text:
But guess what? He won’t allow it for your
children.

2021.85.text:
He went to an independent school that wasn’t
set up by a local authority…

2025.07.text:
…but no, he doesn’t want charities and
parents to set up schools for your children.

2030.14.text:
He had the benefit of world-class teachers
who happened not to have a government certificate…

2034.50.text:
…but no, he wants to stop people like that
from teaching your children.

2039.28.text:
I tell you – Tristram Hunt and I might both
have been educated at some of the best schools

2045.29.text:
in our country.
But here’s the difference:

2048.09.text:
You, Tristram – like the rest of the Labour
Party – want to restrict those advantages…

2052.66.text:
…I want to spread them to every child in
Britain.

2071.47.text:
We know Labour’s real problem on education.
Every move they make, they’ve got to take

2077.47.text:
their cue from the unions.
That’s who they really represent. The unions.

2083.02.text:
Well, I’ve got a bit of news for you.
It’s not something we’ve ever said before.

2091.42.text:
We in this party are a trade union too.
I’ll tell you who we represent.

2098.56.text:
This party is the union for hardworking parents…
…the father who reads his children stories

2103.62.text:
at night because he wants them to learn…
…the mother who works all the hours God

2107.34.text:
sends to give her children the best start.
This party is the trade union for children

2112.39.text:
from the poorest estates and the most chaotic
homes.

2115.26.text:
This party is the union for the young woman
who wants an Apprenticeship…

2118.49.text:
…for the teenagers who want to make something
of their lives…

2121.27.text:
…this is who we represent, these are the
people we’re fighting for…

2124.74.text:
…and that’s why on education we won’t
let Labour drag us back to square one – we’re

2129.46.text:
going to finish what we have begun.
A real education isn’t just about exams.

2150.17.text:
Our young people must know this is a country
where if you put in, you will get out.

2155.03.text:
Now I’ve got in trouble for talking about
Twitter before, but let me put it like this.

2166.08.text:
I want a country where young people aren’t
endlessly thinking: ‘what can I say in 140

2172.21.text:
characters?’ but ‘what does my character
say about me?’

2176.86.text:
That’s why I’m so proud of National Citizen
Service.

2181.68.text:
Every summer, thousands of young people are
coming together to volunteer and serve their

2189.90.text:
People come up to me on the street and say
all sorts of things…

2193.17.text:
…believe me – all sorts of things…
…but one thing I hear a lot is parents saying

2200.42.text:
“thank you for what this has done for my
child.”

2206.42.text:
I want this to become a rite of passage for
all teenagers in our country.

2212.39.text:
So I can tell you this: the next Conservative
Government will guarantee a place on National

2218.11.text:
Citizen Service for every teenager in our
country.

2235.70.text:
That rule: that if you put in, you should
get out…

2238.95.text:
…more than anywhere it should apply to those
who want dignity and security in retirement.

2245.31.text:
But for years it didn’t.
There were three great wrongs.

2251.46.text:
Wrong number one: the Pension Credit that
was basically a means test – the more you

2256.47.text:
saved, the less you got.
Wrong number two: compulsory annuities that

2261.83.text:
meant you couldn’t spend your own money
as you wished.

2264.89.text:
Wrong number three: when people passed away,
the pension they had saved was taxed at 55

2270.75.text:
per cent before it went to their family.
Three wrongs – and we are putting them right.

2277.67.text:
The means test – it’s going.
In its place: a new single-tier pension of

2281.87.text:
£142 a week…
…every penny you have saved during your

2285.77.text:
working life, you will keep.
Those compulsory annuities – scrapped…

2290.20.text:
…giving you complete control over your private
pension.

2294.40.text:
As for that 55 per cent tax on your pension?
You heard it this week: we’ve cut it to

2299.63.text:
zero per cent.
Conservative values in action.

2315.06.text:
When it comes to our elderly, one thing matters
above everything.

2321.83.text:
Knowing the NHS is there for you.
From Labour last week, we heard the same old

2328.26.text:
rubbish about the Conservatives and the NHS.
Spreading complete and utter lies.

2335.29.text:
I just think: how dare you.
It was the Labour Party who gave us the scandal

2340.62.text:
at Mid Staffs…
…elderly people begging for water and dying

2344.19.text:
of neglect.
And for me, this is personal.

2347.91.text:
I am someone who has relied on the NHS – whose
family knows more than most how important

2352.78.text:
it is…
…who knows what it’s like to go to hospital

2355.42.text:
night after night with a child in your arms…
…knowing that when you get there, you have

2359.69.text:
people who will care for that child and love
that child like their own.

2364.67.text:
How dare they suggest I would ever put that
at risk for other people’s children?…

2368.35.text:
…how dare they frighten those who are relying
on the NHS right now?

2381.40.text:
It might be the only thing that gets a cheer
at their Party conference but it is frankly

2405.45.text:
pathetic.
We in this party can be proud of what we’ve

2412.16.text:
done.
We came in and protected the NHS budget.

2417.14.text:
Funding six and a half thousand more doctors
– 3300 more nurses…

2421.85.text:
…a Cancer Drugs Fund to save lives…
…more people hearing those two magic words:

2428.91.text:
“all clear”.
And think of the amazing things around the

2432.72.text:
corner.
From the country that unravelled DNA, we are

2436.78.text:
now mapping it for each individual…
…it’s called the genome, and I’ve got

2441.61.text:
a model of one of the first ones on my desk
in Downing Street.

2445.31.text:
Cracking this code could mean curing rare
genetic diseases and saving lives.

2450.91.text:
Our NHS is leading the world on this incredible
technology.

2454.89.text:
I understand very personally the difference
it could make.

2459.49.text:
When you have a child who’s so ill and the
doctors can’t work out what he’s got or

2463.67.text:
why - you’d give anything to know.
The investment we’re making will mean that

2469.12.text:
more parents have those answers - and hopefully
the cures that go with them.

2473.98.text:
And let’s be clear: all this is only possible
because we have managed our economy responsibly.

2482.73.text:
That is why I can tell you this: we will do
it again.

2489.84.text:
The next Conservative Government will protect
the NHS budget and continue to invest more.

2496.15.text:
Because we know this truth…
… something Labour will never understand

2500.26.text:
– and we will never forget…
…you can only have a strong NHS if you have

2505.83.text:
a strong economy.
A Britain that everyone is proud to call home.

2525.70.text:
A place where reward follows effort; where
if you put in, you get out.

2530.22.text:
But it also means a country that is strong
in the world - in control of its own destiny…

2536.84.text:
…and yes – that includes controlling immigration.
To me, this is about working on all fronts.

2543.66.text:
It’s about getting our own people fit to
work.

2547.58.text:
Fixing welfare – so a life on the dole is
not an option.

2551.01.text:
Fixing education – so we turn out young
people with skills to do the jobs we are creating.

2557.00.text:
And yes – we need controlled borders and
an immigration system that puts the British

2562.20.text:
people first.
That’s why we’ve capped economic migration

2566.82.text:
from outside the EU…
…shut down 700 bogus colleges – that were

2571.69.text:
basically visa factories…
…kicked out people who don’t belong here,

2575.65.text:
like Abu Qatada…
…and let’s hear it for the woman who made

2578.51.text:
it happen: our crime-busting Home Secretary,
Theresa May.

2596.05.text:
But we know the bigger issue today is migration
from within the EU.

2601.40.text:
Immediate access to our welfare system. Paying
benefits to families back home.

2606.88.text:
Employment agencies signing people up from
overseas and not recruiting here.

2611.84.text:
Numbers that have increased faster than we
in this country wanted…

2614.85.text:
…at a level that was too much for our communities,
for our labour markets.

2620.32.text:
All of this has to change – and it will
be at the very heart of my renegotiation strategy

2626.25.text:
for Europe.
Britain, I know you want this sorted so I

2631.07.text:
will go to Brussels, I will not take no for
an answer and when it comes to free movement

2636.27.text:
– I will get what Britain needs.
Anyone who thinks I can’t or won’t deliver

2644.99.text:
this – judge me by my record.
I’m the first Prime Minister to veto a Treaty…

2651.72.text:
…the first Prime Minister to cut the European
budget…

2654.35.text:
…and yes I pulled us out of those European
bail-out schemes as well.

2658.65.text:
Around that table in Europe they know I say
what I mean, and mean what I say.

2663.91.text:
So we’re going to go in as a country, get
our powers back, fight for our national interest…

2668.80.text:
…and yes – we’ll put it to a referendum…
…in or out – it will be your choice…

2672.57.text:
…and let the message go out from this hall:
it is only with a Conservative Government

2676.88.text:
that you will get that choice.
Of course, it’s not just the European Union

2696.56.text:
that needs sorting out – it’s the European
Court of Human Rights.

2702.02.text:
When that charter was written, in the aftermath
of the Second World War, it set out the basic

2707.55.text:
rights we should respect.
But since then, interpretations of that charter

2714.23.text:
have led to a whole lot of things that are
frankly wrong.

2717.65.text:
Rulings to stop us deporting suspected terrorists.
The suggestion that you’ve got to apply

2722.98.text:
the human rights convention even on the battle-fields
of Helmand.

2727.46.text:
And now – they want to give prisoners the
vote.

2730.60.text:
I’m sorry, I just don’t agree.
Our Parliament – the British Parliament

2737.25.text:
– decided they shouldn’t have that right.
This is the country that wrote Magna Carta…

2742.24.text:
…the country that time and again has stood
up for human rights…

2745.47.text:
…whether liberating Europe from fascism
or leading the charge today against sexual

2749.28.text:
violence in war.
Let me put this very clearly:

2753.67.text:
We do not require instruction on this from
judges in Strasbourg.

2768.08.text:
So at long last, with a Conservative Government
after the next election, this country will

2773.39.text:
have a new British Bill of Rights…
…to be passed in our Parliament…

2777.81.text:
…rooted in our values…
…and as for Labour’s Human Rights Act?

2781.74.text:
We will scrap it, once and for all.
So that’s what we offer: a Britain that

2802.09.text:
everyone is proud to call home.
And a very clear plan to get there.

2808.07.text:
Over the next five years we will deliver the
following things:

2817.38.text:
The most competitive corporate taxes in the
G20.

2821.52.text:
Eliminating the budget deficit through spending
cuts, not tax rises.

2826.39.text:
Building 100,000 new Starter Homes.
Letting you pass on your pension tax-free.

2832.69.text:
Ring-fencing NHS spending so not a penny is
cut.

2837.46.text:
Renegotiating in Europe.
Delivering that in-out referendum.

2841.41.text:
Scrapping the Human Rights Act.
No income tax until you earn £12,500.

2846.18.text:
No 40p tax rate until you earn £50,000.
If you want those things, vote for me.

2856.77.text:
If you don’t, vote for the other guy.
And let’s be clear.

2864.43.text:
This is a straight fight.
It doesn’t matter whether Parliament is

2868.39.text:
hung, drawn or quartered, there is only one
real choice.

2873.68.text:
The Conservatives or Labour.
Me in Downing Street, or Ed Miliband in Downing

2879.50.text:
Street.
If you vote UKIP – that’s really a vote

2892.78.text:
…on 7th May you could go to bed with Nigel
Farage, and wake up with Ed Miliband.

2917.86.text:
So this is the big question for that election.
On the things that matter in your life, who

2923.45.text:
do you really trust?
When it comes to your job…

2926.66.text:
…do you trust Labour – who wrecked our
economy – or the Conservatives, who have

2930.20.text:
made this one of the fastest-growing economies
in the West?

2934.04.text:
When it comes to Britain’s future, who do
you trust?

2937.00.text:
Labour – the party of something-for-nothing,
and human wrongs under the banner of human

2940.90.text:
rights…
…or the Conservatives – who believe in

2943.31.text:
something for something, and reward for hard
work?

2946.30.text:
Who do you trust?
…the party of big debt; big spending, big

2950.05.text:
borrowing…
…or the party – our Party – of the first

2953.16.text:
pay cheque, the first chance, the first home…
…the one that is delivering more security,

2958.17.text:
more opportunity, more hope …
…the one that is making this country great

2962.18.text:
again…
…yes, our party, the Conservative Party.

2972.88.text:
We’re making Britain proud again.
Look what we are showing the world.

2986.77.text:
Not just a country that is paying down its
debts…

2988.73.text:
…and going from the deepest recession since
the war to the fastest-growing major advanced

2993.13.text:
economy in the world…
…but at the same time: a country that has

2997.73.text:
kept its promises to the poorest in the world…
…that is leading not following on climate

3002.67.text:
change…
…and that’s just saved our union in one

3006.48.text:
of the greatest shows of democracy the world
has ever seen.

3009.88.text:
We’re making Britain proud again.
Our exports to China doubling…

3019.58.text:
…our manufacturing growing… we’re making
Britain proud again.

3025.27.text:
Car engines – not imported from Germany,
but built down the road in Wolverhampton.

3029.30.text:
New oil rigs – not made in China, but built
on the Tyne.

3034.58.text:
Record levels of employment…
…record numbers of apprenticeships…

3037.48.text:
…Britain regaining its purpose, its pride
and its confidence.

3041.68.text:
We’re at a moment where all the hard work
is finally paying off…

3046.91.text:
…and the light is coming up after some long
dark days.

3051.00.text:
Go back now and we’ll lose all we’ve done…
…falling back into the shadows when we could

3055.73.text:
be striding into the sun.
That’s the question next May.

3061.04.text:
Do you want to go back to square one – or
finish what we’ve begun?

3068.18.text:
I don’t claim to be a perfect leader.
But I am your public servant, standing here,

3077.42.text:
wanting to make our country so much better
- for your children and mine.

3083.06.text:
I love this country, and I will do my duty
by it.

3086.66.text:
We’ve got the track record, the right team…
…to take this plan for our country and turn

3092.17.text:
it into a plan for you.
I think of the millions of people going out

3096.57.text:
to work, wiping the ice off the windscreen
on a winter’s morning…

3100.47.text:
…raising their children as well they can,
working as hard as they can…

3103.97.text:
…doing it for a better future, to make a
good life for them and their families.

3108.38.text:
That is the British spirit – there in our
ordinary days as well as our finest hours.

3113.80.text:
This is a great country and we can be greater
still.

3116.71.text:
Because history is not written for us, but
by us, in the decisions we make today…

3121.61.text:
…and that starts next May.
So Britain: what’s it going to be?

3128.67.text:
I say: let’s not go back to square one.
Let’s finish what we have begun.

3133.48.text:
Let’s build a Britain we are proud to call
home…

3136.10.text: …for you, for your family, for everyone.
